questions.question: What is an atom?
options: The smallest unit of a chemical element that retains its chemical properties
A group of molecules bonded together
A type of chemical reaction
A unit of measurement for energy

questions.question: What does the atomic number of an element represent?
options: The number of neutrons in the nucleus
The number of protons in the nucleus
The total mass of the atom
The number of electrons in the outermost shell

questions.question: What type of bond involves the sharing of electrons between atoms?
options: Ionic bond
Metallic bond
Covalent bond
Hydrogen bond

questions.question: Which state of matter has a definite volume but no definite shape?
options: Solid
Liquid
Gas
Plasma

questions.question: What is the law of conservation of mass?
options: Mass can be created in chemical reactions
Mass can be destroyed in chemical reactions
The total mass of reactants equals the total mass of products
Atoms combine in fixed mass ratios

questions.question: What is one mole of a substance?
options: 1 gram of the substance
6.022 × 10²³ particles of the substance
1 litre of the substance
The molecular weight in kilograms

questions.question: What is the general formula for an alkane?
options: CnH2n
CnH2n+2
CnH2n-2
CnHn

questions.question: What is the rate of reaction?
options: The energy released by a reaction
The change in concentration of a reactant or product per unit time
The temperature at which a reaction starts
The equilibrium constant of a reaction

questions.question: What is enthalpy (H)?
options: The total kinetic energy of a system
A thermodynamic quantity that represents the heat content of a system at constant pressure
The entropy of a reaction
The free energy available for work

questions.question: What does the pH scale measure?
options: The temperature of a solution
The concentration of hydrogen ions (acidity or alkalinity)
The density of a liquid
The pressure of a gas

questions.question: What is the ideal gas law?
options: PV = nRT
P/V = nR/T
PV = RT
P = nRT/V²

questions.question: What is a limiting reagent?
options: The reactant present in the greatest amount
The reactant that is completely consumed first and limits the amount of product
A substance that speeds up the reaction
A reactant with the highest molecular mass

questions.question: What is electronegativity?
options: The ability of an atom to lose electrons
The ability of an atom to attract shared electrons in a covalent bond
The charge of an ion
The number of bonds an atom can form

questions.question: What does Hess's Law state?
options: The enthalpy change of a reaction depends on the path taken
The total enthalpy change is the same regardless of which route the reaction takes
Entropy always increases in spontaneous reactions
Enthalpy and entropy are always equal at equilibrium

questions.question: What is a catalyst?
options: A substance that increases activation energy
A substance that lowers the activation energy and speeds up a reaction without being consumed
A substance that changes the products of a reaction
A substance consumed in the rate-determining step

questions.question: What is entropy (S)?
options: The energy content of a system
A measure of the disorder or randomness of a system
The temperature of a chemical reaction
The equilibrium constant of a reaction

questions.question: What is a precipitation reaction?
options: A reaction that produces a gas
A reaction where an insoluble solid forms from two solutions
A reaction that releases heat
A reaction involving acids and metals

questions.question: What is nuclear fission?
options: The fusion of two small nuclei
The splitting of a large nucleus into smaller nuclei, releasing energy
The emission of electrons from a nucleus
The capture of a neutron by a stable nucleus

questions.question: What functional group is present in alcohols?
options: Carbonyl group (C=O)
Hydroxyl group (-OH)
Carboxyl group (-COOH)
Amino group (-NH2)

questions.question: When is Gibbs free energy negative (ΔG < 0)?
options: When the reaction is non-spontaneous
When the reaction is spontaneous
When the reaction is at equilibrium
When the activation energy is high
